title: Knob Lick, Missouri
text:
Knob Lick is an <a href="Unincorporated%20area">unincorporated community</a> in southern <a href="Saint%20Francois%20County%2C%20Missouri">Saint Francois County</a>, <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a>, United States. It is located on <a href="Missouri%20Route%20DD">Missouri Route DD</a>, just east of <a href="U.S.%20Route%2067%20in%20Missouri">U.S. Route 67</a>, approximately eight miles south of <a href="Farmington%2C%20Missouri">Farmington</a>.
Knob Lick has a <a href="United%20States%20Postal%20Service">post office</a> with <a href="ZIP%20code">zip code</a> 63651, which has been in operation since 1870.
The community takes its name from nearby Knob Lick Mountain. In the <a href="Ozarks">Ozarks</a>, "knob" typically refers to an isolated summit, and "lick" is a natural "<a href="salt%20lick">salt lick</a>" or <a href="salt">salt</a> <a href="spring%20%28water%29">spring</a>. The mountain is across <a href="U.S.%20Route%2067">U.S. Route 67</a> from the town at . Eighty of the summit are protected by the <a href="Missouri%20Department%20of%20Conservation">Missouri Department of Conservation</a>. A <a href="gravel">gravel</a> road leads to the <a href="conservation%20area">conservation area</a> which includes a <a href="granite">granite</a> <a href="glade%20%28geography%29">glade</a>, picnic facilities, and a closed <a href="fire%20lookout%20tower">fire lookout tower</a>.
